  booktitle = {Proc. Fifth Int. Seminar on Relational Methods in Computer
    Science},
  site = {Qu{\'e}bec, Canada},
  pages = {45--54},
  year = {2000},
  url = {http://www.lsi.upc.es/~valiente/abs-relmics-2000.pdf},
  abstract = {This paper presents a novel approach to the problem of finding
    all subgraph isomorphisms of a (pattern) graph into another (target)
    graph. A relational formulation of the problem, combined with a representation
    of relations and graphs by Boolean functions, allows to handle the combinatorial
    explosion in the case of small pattern graphs and large target graphs
    by using Binary Decision Diagrams (BDDs), which are capable to represent
    large relations and graphs in small data structures. Examples are presented
    that show how all subgraph isomorphisms (120303) of a small graph into
    a large graph can be efficiently computed and represented with a small
    BDD (57980 nodes).}}

@techreport{CosCroSan-TR-86,
  title = {{Subgraph isomorphism on the BBN Butterfly multiprocessor}},
  author = {J. Costanzo and L. A. Crowl and L. Sanchis and M. Srinivas},
  type = {Butterfly Project Report},
  institution = {Univ. of Rochester, Dept. of Computer Science},
  number = {14},
  year = {1986},
  url = {http://www.cs.orst.edu/~crowl/paper/subjects/isomorphism_subgraph_parallel/1986R-URCS-BPR-14/},
  abstract = {This report describes an algorithm for finding subgraph isomorphisms
    for a restricted class of graphs and a parallel implementation of the
    algorithm on the BBN Butterfly Multiprocessor. This effort was part of
    a larger project to assess the suitability of the Butterfly architecture
    for a variety of machine vision tasks. Our algorithm searches a tree
    in which each node represents a partial assignment of vertices in the
    smaller graph to vertices in the larger graph. The algorithm prunes the
    search tree using properties of the two graphs as constrained by the
    partial mapping. These properties are vertex connectivity, distance between
    vertices, and the local topology of vertex clusters. By carefully balancing
    the computational load and the contention for shared resources, our algorithm
    achieves almost linear speedup in the processing rate of search tree
    nodes. However, the speedup of isomorphism detection rate is poor when
    looking for few isomorphisms, and good only when looking for many isomorphisms.
    We present an analysis of why we believe this property is intrinsic to
    algorithms that parallelize the tree search without parallelizing the
    node computations. We also discuss the effectiveness of the Butterfly
    architecture and programming environment in implementing such parallel
    algorithms.}}

@article{CraSmi-CICS-83,
  title = {{Computer-assisted examination of compounds for common three-dimensional
    substructures}},
  author = {C. W. Crandell and D. H. Smith},
  journal = {J. Chemical Information and Computer Sciences},
  volume = {23},
  pages = {186--197},
  year = {1983},
  abstract = {A program for finding common three-dimensional substructures
    within a set of chemical compounds is described. The program allows a
    user to define what constitutes commonality of substructures by providing
    control over the importance of degree of substitution, atom type, aromaticity,
    and hybridization. Simple examples are used to illustrate various phases
    of the search process, and an application of the program to a structure/activity
    problem is used as a more realistic example.}}

@article{CriLyn-ISPP-89,
  title = {{Subgraphs of reduced chemical graphs as screens for substructure
    searching of specific chemical structures}},
  author = {J. K. Cringean and M. F. Lynch},
  journal = {J. Information Science, Principles {\&} Practice},
  volume = {15},
  pages = {211--222},
  year = {1989},
  abstract = {Reduced chemical graphs are descriptions of chemical structures
    which summarize certain structural features (for instance the ring or
    chain nature of components) and conserve certain topological relationships.
    They have proved valuable in representing and searching generic chemical
    structure information. The generation of all subgraphs of one type of
    reduced chemical graph and their use as screens for substructure searching
    of databases of specific chemical structures are described. The subgraphs
    have the potential to provide a single key for each substructure search
    query which comprises a single connected fragment with possible advantages
    in an inverted file substructure search system. The methods and costs
    of generating the subgraphs and their effectiveness in search, are assessed.}}

@inproceedings{CriLynMan-OIM-89,
  title = {{Parallel processing techniques for information retrieval. Searching
    of textual and chemical databases using transputer networks}},
  author = {J. K. Cringean and M. F. Lynch and G. A. Manson and P. Willett
    and G. A. Wilson},
  booktitle = {Proc. 13th International Online Information Mtg., London},
  publisher = {Learned Information},
  address = {Oxford, UK},
  pages = {447--462},
  year = {1989},
  abstract = {Reports the implementation of chemical substructure searching
    and text retrieval algorithms on networks of transputers, high performance
    microprocessors that have been developed specifically for the construction
    of parallel computing systems. The networks are based on the processor
    farm model of computation, which provides an appropriate environment
    for the parallel implementation of applications that require the matching
    of some sort of query record against large numbers of database records.
    The results that have been obtained demonstrate that near-linear speed-ups
    can be achieved if, and only if, it is possible to keep the processors
    in a farm fully occupied with computational work. In such cases, transputers
    provide an extremely cost-effective way of substantially increasing the
    performance of microcomputer-based information retrieval systems.}}

@article{CroCroLeB-JPDC-94,
  title = {{The advantages of multiple parallelizations in combinatorial
    search}},
  author = {L. A. Crowl and M. E. Crovella and T. J. LeBlanc and M. L. Scott},
  journal = {J. Par. Dist. Comput.},
  volume = {21},
  pages = {110--123},
  year = {1994},
  url = {http://www.cs.orst.edu/~crowl/paper/subjects/isomorphism_subgraph_parallel/1994J-JPDC-01-110/},
  abstract = {Applications typically have several potential sources of parallelism,
    and in choosing a particular parallelization, the programmer must balance
    the benefits of each source of parallelism with the corresponding overhead.
    The trade-offs are often difficult to analyze, as they may depend on
    the hardware architecture, software environment, input data, and properties
    of the algorithm. An example of this dilemma occurs in a wide range of
    problems that involve processing trees, wherein processors can be assigned
    either to separate subtrees, or to parallelizing the work performed on
    individual tree nodes. We explore the complexity of the trade-offs involved
    in this decision by considering alternative parallelizations of combinatorial
    search, examining the factors that determine the best-performing implementation
    for this important class of problems. Using subgraph isomorphism as a
    representative search problem, we show how the density of the solution
    space, the number of solutions desired, the number of available processors,
    and the underlying architecture all affect the choice of an efficient
    parallelization. Our experiments, which span seven different shared-memory
    multiprocessors and a wide range of input graphs, indicate that relative
    performance depends on each of these factors. On some machines and for
    some inputs, a sequential depth-first search of the solution space, applying
    simple loop-level parallelism at each node in the search tree, performs
    best. On other machines or other inputs, parallel tree search performs
    best. In still other cases, a hybrid solution, containing both parallel
    tree search and loop parallelism, works best. We present a quantitative
    analysis that explains these results and present experimental data culled
    from thousands of program executions that validates the analysis.}}

@techreport{CroCroLeB-TR-92,
  title = {{The advantages of multiple parallelizations in combinatorial
    search}},
  author = {L. A. Crowl and M. E. Crovella and T. J. LeBlanc and M. L. Scott},

@inproceedings{Dam-WG-90,
  title = {{Induced subgraph isomorphism for cographs is NP-complete}},
  author = {P. Damaschke},
  booktitle = {Proc. 16th Int. Worksh. Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer
    Science},
  number = {484},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {72--78},
  year = {1991},
  abstract = {Proves by a reduction from 3SAT that the induced subgraph isomorphism
    problem remains NP-complete when restricted to cographs ($P_4$-free graphs).}}

@article{DesLinPro-Algo-00,
  title = {{Faster algorithms for subgraph isomorphism of $k$-connected partial
    $k$-trees}},
  author = {A. Dessmark and Andrzej Lingas and A. Proskurowski},
  journal = {Algorithmica},
  volume = {27},
  number = {3},
  pages = {337--347},
  year = {2000},
  abstract = {The problem of determining whether a $k$-connected partial
    $k$-tree is isomorphic to a subgraph of another partial $k$-tree is shown
    to be solvable in time $O(n^{k+2})$. The presented time-bounds considerably
    improve the corresponding bounds known in the literature. They rely in
    part on a new characterization of width-$k$ tree-decomposition of $k$-connected
    partial $k$-trees.}}

@article{DiaSerTor-AI-96,
  title = {{Parallel approximation schemes for problems on planar graphs}},
  author = {J. D{\'\i}az and M. J. Serna and J. T{\'o}ran},
  journal = {Acta Informatica},
  volume = {33},
  number = {4},
  pages = {387--408},
  year = {1996}}

@inproceedings{DilSmi-SCG-92,
  title = {{A linear-time algorithm for testing the inscribability of trivalent
    polyhedra}},
  author = {Michael B. Dillencourt and Warren D. Smith},
  booktitle = {Proc. 8th Symp. Computational Geometry},
  publisher = {Assoc. Comput. Mach.},
  pages = {177--185},
  year = {1992},
  comment = {Uses Chiba {\&} Nishizeki's planar triangle listing algorithm.},
  abstract = {The authors present an algorithm for testing the inscribability
    of a trivalent polyhedron or, equivalently, testing the circumscribability
    of a simplicial polyhedron. Their algorithm runs in linear time, using
    only low-precision integer arithmetic. The algorithm is based on a purely
    combinatorial characterization of inscribable trivalent polyhedra.}}

@inproceedings{DonWuDin-CPCOL-88,
  title = {{A multi-font Chinese character recognition method based on the
    attributed relational graph (ARG) representation}},
  author = {Dong{ }Hong and Youshou Wu and Xiaoqing Ding},
  booktitle = {Proc. Int. Conf. Computer Processing of Chinese and Oriental
    Languages},
  pages = {156--160},
  year = {1988},
  abstract = {Presents a new multi-font Chinese character recognition method
    based on the two-layer hierarchical ARG representation of Chinese characters.
    As first rough classification, 56 kinds of radicals are extracted by
    inexact subgraph matching. Then a distance measure is defined between
    characters based on matching the four sub-pattern strings formed by ordering
    the character strokes, which can be calculated by dynamic programming.
    To further reduce the character number in each group after first rough
    classification, a clustering method, which makes use of relative distance,
    is proposed to divide the characters in a group into several clusters.
    Finally recognition results are obtained using minimum distance criterion.}}

@inproceedings{DonWuDin-ICPR-88,
  title = {{An ARG representation for Chinese characters and a radical extraction
    based on the representation}},
  author = {Dong{ }Hong and Youshou Wu and Xiaoqing Ding},
  booktitle = {Proc. 9th Int. Conf. Pattern Recognition},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  volume = {2},
  pages = {920--922},
  year = {1988},
  abstract = {Based on the analysis of structural characteristics of Chinese
    characters, a hierarchical attributed relational representation for Chinese
    characters is proposed. This representation is structurally stable to
    different fonts or even hand-printed Chinese characters. Based on the
    representation, a radical extraction method is presented. This approach
    solves the radical extraction problem by searching subgraph isomorphism
    or E-subgraph matching.}}

@inproceedings{Dor-WG-94,
  title = {{Bypass strong V-structures and find an isomorphic labelled subgraph
    in linear time}},
  author = {H. Dorr},
  booktitle = {Proc. 20th Int. Worksh. Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer
    Science},
  number = {903},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {305--318},
  year = {1994},
  abstract = {This paper identifies a condition for which the existence of
    an isomorphic subgraph can be decided in linear time. The condition is
    evaluated in two steps. First the host graph is analysed to determine
    its strong V-structures. Then the guest graph must be appropriately represented.
    If this representation exists, the given algorithm constructively decides
    the subgraph isomorphism problem. For the guest and the host graph in
    linear time. The result applies especially to the implementation of graph
    rewriting systems. An isomorphic subgraph must be determined automatically
    in each rewriting step. Thus the efficient solution presented in this
    paper is an important advancement for any implementation project.}}

@article{DroMac-JCTA-91,
  title = {{On $k$-homogeneous posets and graphs}},
  author = {M. Droste and H. D. MacPherson},
  journal = {J. Combinatorial Theory, Series A},
  volume = {56},
  pages = {1--15},
  year = {1991},
  abstract = {A relational structure $A$ is called $k$-homogeneous if each
    isomorphism between two $k$-element substructures of $A$ extends to an
    automorphism of $A$. The authors show that if a countable poset $(\Omega,\le)$
    is 1- and 4-homogeneous, then it is $k$-homogeneous for each $k$ in $N$.
    There are infinitely many examples of $\Aleph_0$-categorical universal
    countable posets $(\Omega,\le)$ showing that here the number 4 may not
    be replaced by 2 or 3. The authors also show that for every $k$ in N
    there are continuously many countable $\Aleph_0$-categorical universal
    graphs which are $k$-homogeneous but not $(k+1)$-homogeneous; this answers
    a question of R. Fraisse (1986).}}

@phdthesis{Dru-PhD-75,
  title = {{Graph related algorithms: isomorphism, automorphism, and containment}},
  author = {L. E. Druffel},
  school = {Vanderbilt Univ.},
  year = {1975},
  abstract = {The three related problems of graph isomorphism, graph automorphism
    and subgraph containment are considered and algorithms proposed for each.}}

@article{Dub-IPL-90,
  title = {{Some comments on the subtree isomorphism problem for ordered
    trees}},
  author = {P. Dublish},
  journal = {Information Processing Letters},
  volume = {36},
  pages = {273--275},
  year = {1990},
  abstract = {A linear time algorithm for the subtree isomorphism problem
    for rooted ordered trees has recently been presented by Makinen \cite{Mak-IPL-89}.
    However, the author claims that there are several fallacies in Makinen's
    paper and the algorithm he gives is wrong. Makinen has also confused
    the issue by not precisely defining the problem being solved. The author
    is aware of two distinct versions of the subtree isomorphism problem.
    He gives counterexamples to show that Makinen's algorithm fails to solve
    these problems for rooted ordered trees. He also gives linear time algorithms
    for the two versions of the subtree isomorphism problem for rooted ordered
    trees.}}

@article{DufGinRod-RSA-95,
  title = {{On the computational complexity of ordered subgraph recognition}},
  author = {D. Duffus and M. Ginn and V. Rodl},
  journal = {Random Structures and Algorithms},
  volume = {7},
  pages = {223--268},
  year = {1995},
  abstract = {Let $(G,<)$ be a finite graph $G$ with a linearly ordered vertex
    set $V$. We consider the decision problem $(G,<)$-ORD to have as an instance
    an (unordered) graph $\Gamma$ and as a question whether there exists
    a linear order $<$ on $V(\Gamma)$ and an order preserving graph isomorphism
    of $(G,<)$ onto an induced subgraph of $\Gamma$. Several familiar classes
    of graph are characterized as the yes instances of $(G,<)$-ORD for appropriate
    choices of $(G,<)$. Here the complexity of $(G,<)$-ORD is investigated.
    We conjecture that for any 2-connected graph $G$, $G\ne K_k$, $(G,<)$-ORD
    is NP complete. This is verified for almost all 2-connected graphs. Several
    related problems are formulated and discussed.}}

@inproceedings{EllLeh-ICCS-94,
  title = {{Exploiting the induced order on type-labeled graphs for fast
    knowledge retrieval}},
  author = {G. Ellis and F. Lehmann},
  booktitle = {Proc. 2nd Int. Conf. Conceptual Structures: Current Practices},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {293--310},
  year = {1994},
  abstract = {The graph structure of a conceptual graph can be used for efficient
    retrieval in complex (graphical) object databases. The aim is to replace
    most graph matching with efficient operations on precompiled codes for
    graphs. The unlabeled graph or `skeleton' of a type-labeled conceptual
    graph (without negated contexts) can be used as a filter for matching,
    subsumption testing, and unification. For two type-labeled graphs to
    match, their skeletons must first match. One type-labeled graph can subsume
    another only if its skeleton is included in that of the other. A skeleton-inclusion
    hierarchy can be constructed for a useful set of all possible skeletons
    up to a certain size. That hierarchy is then embedded in a Boolean lattice
    of bit-strings. Expensive graph comparison operations are traded for
    very fast bit-string logic operations on the codes. New graphs can be
    encoded at run time without recompiling the whole hierarchy: having found
    a graph's structural type, the authors then use it to hash to the code
    encoding the poset of all possible type-labeled graphs ordered by subsumption.
    Some of the order in that poset comes from the subgraph inclusion factor
    while other order comes from the `type-lattice' (on concept-labels) factor.
    It is shown how they relate. The authors are investigating the bounds
    on code length and new methods of factorisation of conceptual graph databases.}}

@article{EngWah-PR-88,
  title = {{Polyhedral object recognition using Hough-space features}},
  author = {J. R. Engelbrecht and F. M. Wahl},
  journal = {Pattern Recognition},
  volume = {21},
  pages = {155--167},
  year = {1988},
  abstract = {Proposes a new technique for three-dimensional (3-D) polyhedral
    object recognition on the basis of a single two-dimensional (2-D) view
    of a 3-D scene. The binary gradient image of the captured scene is converted
    into the Hough-space domain. The cluster patterns originating from straight-line
    features of the image are explored by reasoning in Hough space. This
    yields an attributed graph representation of the object to be recognized
    which is compared to similar representations of CAD-designed wire frame
    model objects by means of a new attributed subgraph isomorphism algorithm.}}

@article{Epp-Algo-?,
  title = {{Diameter and treewidth in minor-closed graph families}},
  author = {David Eppstein},
  eprint = {math.CO/9907126},
  journal = {Algorithmica},
  note = {To appear}}

@article{Epp-IPL-94,
  title = {{Arboricity and bipartite subgraph listing algorithms}},
  author = {David Eppstein},
  journal = {Information Processing Letters},
  volume = {51},
  pages = {207--211},
  year = {1994},
  abstract = {In graphs of bounded arboricity, the total complexity of all
    maximal complete bipartite subgraphs is $O(n)$. We describe a linear
    time algorithm to list such subgraphs. The arboricity bound is necessary:
    for any constant $k$ and any $n$ there exists an $n$-vertex graph with
    $O(n)$ edges and $(n/\log{n})^k$ maximal complete bipartite subgraphs
    $K_{k,l}$.}}

@article{Epp-JGAA-99,
  title = {{Subgraph isomorphism in planar graphs and related problems}},
  author = {David Eppstein},
  eprint = {cs.DS/9911003},
  journal = {J. Graph Algorithms {\&} Applications},
  volume = {3},
  number = {3},
  pages = {1--27},
  year = {1999}}

@article{Epp-JGT-93,
  title = {{Connectivity, graph minors, and subgraph multiplicity}},
  author = {David Eppstein},
  journal = {J. Graph Theory},
  volume = {17},
  pages = {409--416},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {It is well known that any planar graph contains at most $O(n)$
    complete subgraphs. We extend this to an exact characterization: $G$
    occurs $O(n)$ times as a subgraph of any planar graph, if and only if
    $G$ is three-connected. We generalize these results to similarly characterize
    certain other minor-closed families of graphs; in particular, $G$ occurs
    $O(n)$ times as a subgraph of the $K_{b,c}$-free graphs, $b\ge c$ and
    $c\le 4$, iff $G$ is $c$-connected. Our results use a simple Ramsey-theoretic
    lemma that may be of independent interest.}}

@inproceedings{Epp-SODA-95,
  title = {{Subgraph isomorphism in planar graphs and related problems}},
  author = {David Eppstein},
  eprint = {cs.DS/9911003},
  booktitle = {Proc. 6th Symp. Discrete Algorithms},
  publisher = {Assoc. Comput. Mach. and Soc. Industrial {\&} Applied Math.},
  pages = {632--640},
  year = {1995},
  abstract = {We solve the subgraph isomorphism problem in planar graphs
    in linear time, for any pattern of constant size. Our results are based
    on a technique of partitioning the planar graph into pieces of small
    tree-width, and applying dynamic programming within each piece. The same
    methods can be used to solve other planar graph problems including diameter,
    girth, induced subgraph isomorphism, and shortest paths. We also extend
    our techniques to other families of graphs including the graphs of bounded
    genus.}}

@article{EppGalIta-SJC-99,
  title = {{Separator based sparsification II: edge and vertex connectivity}},
  author = {David Eppstein and Zvi Galil and Giuseppe F. Italiano and Thomas
    H. Spencer},
  journal = {SIAM J. Computing},
  publisher = {Soc. Industrial {\&} Applied Math.},
  volume = {28},
  number = {1},
  pages = {341--381},
  year = {1999}}

@article{EshFu-PAMI-86,
  title = {{An image understanding system using attributed symbolic representation
    and inexact graph-matching}},
  author = {M. A. Eshera and K. S. Fu},
  journal = {Trans. Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  volume = {8},
  pages = {604--619},
  year = {1986},
  abstract = {Presents a powerful image understanding system that utilizes
    a semantic-syntactic (or attributed-symbolic) representation scheme in
    the form of attributed relational graphs (ARGs) for comprehending the
    global information contents of images. Nodes in the ARG represent the
    global image features, while the relations between those features are
    represented by attributed branches between their corresponding nodes.
    The extraction of ARG representations from images is achieved by a multilayer
    graph transducer scheme. This scheme is a rule-based system that uses
    a combination of model-driven and data-driven concepts in performing
    a hierarchical symbolic mapping of the image information content from
    the spatial-domain representation into a global representation. Further
    analysis and interpretation of the imagery data is performed on the extracted
    ARG representation. Two illustrative experiments demonstrate some capabilities
    of the proposed system. One deals with locating objects in multiobject
    scenes, while the other is concerned with target detection in SAR images.}}

@inproceedings{FelKraMid-GST-93,
  title = {{Induced minors and related problems}},
  author = {Michael R. Fellows and Jan Kratochv{\'\i}l and Matthias Middendorf
    and Frank Pfeiffer},
  booktitle = {Graph Structure Theory: Proc. Joint Summer Conf. Graph Minors},
  number = {147},
  series = {Contemporary Mathematics},
  publisher = {Amer. Math. Soc.},
  pages = {179--182},
  year = {1993}}

@inproceedings{FelLan-STOC-89,
  title = {{On search, decision and the efficiency of polynomial-time algorithms}},
  author = {Michael R. Fellows and Michael A. Langston},
  booktitle = {Proc. 21st Symp. Theory of Computing},
  publisher = {Assoc. Comput. Mach.},
  pages = {501--512},
  year = {1989}}

@inproceedings{Fer-IGARSS-86,
  title = {{Shape similarity in remote sensing images using graph matching
    techniques}},
  author = {S. Fernandez},
  booktitle = {Proc. IGARSS '86, Remote Sensing: Today's Solutions for Tomorrow's
    Information Needs},
  volume = {2},
  pages = {1005--1009},
  year = {1986},
  abstract = {The method described in the first approach to detection of
    loosely defined objects in a remotely sensed image. The objects are two
    dimensional in nature and have a graph structure given by the linear
    features found in most of the available images. The first step in the
    procedure is to extract a condensed description of the image in terms
    of graphs through edge detection, edge thinning, and edge following to
    detect points of intersection and of maximal curvature. Given a similar
    description of an object, a graph matching algorithm with forward checking
    and backtracking is used to find the matching subgraph, based on the
    accumulated error in the angles between adjacent nodes as a measure of
    dissimilarity.}}

@article{FerVal-PRL-01,
  title = {{A graph distance measure combining maximum common subgraph and
    minimum common supergraph}},
  author = {Mirtha-Lina Fern{\'a}ndez and Gabriel Valiente},
  journal = {Pattern Recognition Letters},
  volume = {22},
  number = {6--7},
  pages = {753--758},
  year = {2001},
  abstract = {The relationship between two important problems in pattern
    recognition using attributed relational graphs, the maximum common subgraph
    and the minimum common supergraph of two graphs, is established by means
    of simple constructions, which allow to obtain the maximum common subgraph
    from the minimum common supergraph, and vice versa. On this basis, a
    new graph distance metric is proposed for measuring similarities between
    objects represented by attributed relational graphs. The proposed metric
    can be computed by a straightforward extension of any algorithm that
    implements error-correcting graph matching, when run under an appropriate
    cost function, and the extension only takes time linear in the size of
    the graphs.}}

@article{FigKeh-TAES-88,
  title = {{Model-based orientation-independent 3-D machine vision techniques}},
  author = {De Figueiredo, Rui J. P. and N. Kehtarnavaz},
  journal = {Trans. Aerospace and Electronic Systems},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  volume = {24},
  pages = {597--607},
  year = {1988},
  abstract = {Orientation-dependent techniques for the identification of
    a three-dimensional (3-D) object by a machine vision system are represented
    in parts. In the first part, the data consist of intensity images of
    polyhedral objects obtained by a single camera, while in the second part,
    the data consist of range images of curved objects obtained by a laser
    scanner. In both cases, the attributed graph representation of the 3-D
    object surface is used to drive the respective algorithm. In this representation,
    a graph node represents a surface path and a link, the adjacency between
    two patches. The attributes assigned to nodes are moment invariants of
    the corresponding face for polyhedral objects. For range images, the
    Gaussian curvature is used as a segmentation criterion for providing
    symbolic shape attributes. Identification is achieved by an efficient
    graph-matching algorithm used to match the graph obtained from the data
    to a subgraph of one of the model graphs stored in the computer memory.}}

@article{ForHopWyl-TCS-80,
  title = {{The directed subgraph homeomorphism problem}},
  author = {S. Fortune and John Hopcroft and J. Wyllie},
  journal = {Theoretical Computer Science},
  volume = {10},
  pages = {111--121},
  year = {1980},
  abstract = {The set of pattern graphs for which the fixed directed subgraph
    homeomorphism problem is NP-complete is characterized. A polynomial time
    algorithm is given for the remaining cases. The restricted problem where
    the input graph is a directed acyclic graph is in polynomial time for
    all pattern graphs and an algorithm is given.}}

@article{Fou-JCTB-93,
  title = {{A strengthening of Ben Rebea's lemma}},
  author = {J. L. Fouquet},
  journal = {J. Combinatorial Theory, Series B},
  volume = {59},
  pages = {35--40},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {Presents a strengthening of a lemma due to A. Ben Rebea (1981)
    and used by V. Chvatal and N. Sbihi (1988) for the recognition of claw-free
    perfect graphs. The author shows that a claw-free graph with stability
    number at least four has no induced subgraph isomorphic to a $C_{2p+1}$
    with $p\ge 3$. As a by-product he shows that every vertex in a claw-free
    graph with stability number at least three is such that its neighbourhood
    can be covered by two complete graphs or contains an induced $C_5$.}}

@article{Fre-SJC-87,
  title = {{Fast algorithms for shortest paths in planar graphs, with applications}},
  author = {G. N. Frederickson},
  journal = {SIAM J. Computing},
  publisher = {Soc. Industrial {\&} Applied Math.},
  volume = {16},
  pages = {1004--1022},
  year = {1987}}

@article{Fre-SJC-97,
  title = {{Ambivalent data structures for dynamic 2-edge-connectivity and
    $k$ smallest spanning trees}},
  author = {Greg N. Frederickson},
  keywords = {minimum spanning trees, suboptimal solutions, tree data structure\
    s},
  journal = {SIAM J. Comput.},
  publisher = {SIAM},
  volume = {26},
  number = {2},
  pages = {484--538},
  month = {April},
  year = {1997}}

@techreport{Fre-TR-84,
  title = {{Utilizing Subgraph Isomorphism in Constraint Graphs}},
  author = {E. C. Freuder},
  institution = {Univ. of New Hampshire, Dept. of Computer Science},
  number = {84-13},
  year = {1984}}

@article{FreJan-SJC-89,
  title = {{Efficient message routing in planar networks}},
  author = {G. N. Frederickson and R. Janardan},
  journal = {SIAM J. Computing},
  publisher = {Soc. Industrial {\&} Applied Math.},
  volume = {18},
  pages = {843--857},
  year = {1989},
  comment = {Cited by Epp95 which includes a different routing structure
    based on the subgraph isomorphism ideas in that paper},
  abstract = {The problem of routing messages along near-shortest paths in
    a distributed network without using complete routing tables is considered.
    It is assumed that the nodes of the network can be assigned suitable
    short names at the time the network is established. Two space-efficient
    near-shortest-path routing schemes are given for the class of planar
    networks. Both schemes use the separator property of planar networks
    in assigning the node names and performing the routings. For an n-node
    network, the first scheme uses O(log n)-bit names and a total of O(n{$^\wedge$}4/3)
    items of routing information, each O(log n) bits long, to generate routings
    that are only three times longer than corresponding shortest routings
    in worst case. For any constant epsilon, 0 {$<$} epsilon {$<$} 1/3, the second
    scheme achieves the better space bound of O(n{$^\wedge$}1+epsilon)items, each O((1/epsilon)log
    n) bits long, but at the expense of O((1/epsilon)log n)-bit node names
    and a worst-case bound of 7 on the routings.}}

@article{FreJan-SJC-90,
  title = {{Space-efficient message routing in $c$-decomposable networks}},
  author = {G. N. Frederickson and R. Janardan},
  journal = {SIAM J. Computing},
  publisher = {Soc. Industrial {\&} Applied Math.},
  volume = {19},
  pages = {14--30},
  year = {1990},
  abstract = {Message routing strategies are given for networks with certain
    separator properties. These strategies use considerably less space than
    complete routing tables, keep node names to O (log n) bits, and still
    route along near-shortest paths. For any network with separators of size
    at most a small constant c, a total of O(n log n) items of routing information
    is stored, and any message is routed along a path of length at most (2/
    alpha )+1 times the length of an optimal path, where alpha is a parameter
    of the network. For planar networks, O(n/sup 1+e/) items are stored,
    for any c epsilon such that 0{$<$} epsilon {$<$}1/3, and the length of any message
    path is at most 7 times that of an optimal path.}}

@article{Gab-JCSS-95,
  title = {{A matroid approach to finding edge connectivity and packing arborescences}},
  author = {H. N. Gabow},
  journal = {J. Computer {\&} System Sciences},
  volume = {50},
  pages = {259--273},
  year = {1995},
  abstract = {We present an algorithm that finds the edge connectivity lambda
    of a graph having n vertices and m edges. The running time is O( lambda
    m log(n/sup 2//m)) for directed graphs and slightly less for undirected
    graphs, O(m+ lambda /sup 2/n log(n/ lambda )). This improves the previous
    best time bounds, O(min(mn, lambda /sup 2/n/sup 2/)) for directed graphs
    and O( lambda n/sup 2/) for undirected graphs. We present an algorithm
    that finds k edge-disjoint arborescences on a directed graph in time
    O((kn)/sup 2/). This improves the previous best time bound, O(kmn+k/sup
    3/n/sup 2/). Unlike previous work, our approach is based on two theorems
    of J. Edmonds that link these two problems and show how they can be solved.}}

@book{GarJoh-79,
  title = {{Computers and intractability: a guide to the theory of NP-completeness}},
  author = {M. R. Garey and David S. Johnson},
  publisher = {W. H. Freeman},
  year = {1979}}

@article{GarRey-TC-93,
  title = {{Prolog representation of molecular structures and pattern recognition}},
  author = {E. Garcia and L. M. Reyes},
  journal = {THEOCHEM},
  volume = {101},
  pages = {175--185},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {Research regarding representation of chemical structures in
    computers has been performed since the 1970s, with two central goals:
    information manipulation in chemical databases and computer assisted
    molecular synthesis. The work is involved with the latter subject. The
    authors show the need for a general flexible and efficient form of representation
    based on, weighted graphs. Some algorithms for structural pattern recognition,
    such as functional groups, reaction sites, rings, isomorphism and topological
    symmetry have been developed. These algorithms were implemented in Prolog,
    a declarative language, used because of its facilities in symbolic computations
    and its natural back-tracking capability. With the use of this representation
    the authors have created a working environment that is simple and effective
    for the automatic manipulation of chemical structures. This framework
    also allows easy transformations between different representations, such
    as connectivity matrices, line notation or topological codes based on
    path counts, among others, allowing exploration of the particular advantages
    of each.}}

@inproceedings{GibKarMil-AWOC-88,
  title = {{Subtree isomorphism is in random NC}},
  author = {P. B. Gibbons and Richard M. Karp and Gary L. Miller and D. Soroker},
  booktitle = {Proc. 3rd Aegean Worksh. Computing, VLSI Algorithms and Architectures},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {43--52},
  year = {1988}}

@article{GibKarMil-DAM-90,
  title = {{Subtree isomorphism is in random NC}},
  author = {P. B. Gibbons and Richard M. Karp and Gary L. Miller and D. Soroker},
  journal = {Discrete Applied Mathematics},
  volume = {29},
  pages = {35--62},
  year = {1990},
  abstract = {Given two trees, a guest tree G and a host tree H, the subtree
    isomorphism problem is to determine whether there is a subgraph of H
    that is isomorphic to G. The authors present a randomized parallel algorithm
    for finding such an isomorphism, if it exists. The algorithm runs in
    time $O(\log^3 n)$ on a CREW PRAM, where n is the number of nodes in
    H. The number of processors required by the algorithm is polynomial in
    n. Randomization is used (solely) to solve each of a series of bipartite
    matching problems during the course of the algorithm. The authors demonstrate
    the close connection between the two problems by presenting a log-space
    reduction from bipartite perfect matching to subtree isomorphism. Finally,
    they present some techniques to reduce the number of processors used
    by the algorithm.}}

@article{GilWelLyn-CICS-86,
  title = {{Computer storage and retrieval of generic chemical structures
    in patents. VII. Parallel simulation of a relaxation algorithm for chemical
    substructure search}},
  author = {V. J. Gillet and S. M. Welford and M. F. Lynch and P. Willett
    and J. M. Barnard and G. M. Downs},
  journal = {J. Chemical Information and Computer Sciences},
  volume = {26},
  pages = {118--126},
  year = {1986},
  abstract = {For pt.VI see ibid., vol.24, no.2, p.66-71 (1984). A relaxation
    algorithm for chemical substructure search is simulated for implementation
    on general-purpose multiprocessors. An improved relaxation algorithm
    is described and the inherent parallelism detailed. The general-purpose
    simulation package PASSIM is described, and the methods used to simulate
    the algorithm are given. A variably sized pool of processors was assumed.
    The simulation was run on 71 structure/query pairs, and an average maximum
    speedup of 5.5 over a single processor was found, for approximately 20
    processors. A great variation is found for individual structure/query
    pairs. The overall factor limiting the performance is the serial bottlenecks
    in the algorithm.}}

@inproceedings{GmuBun-IASTED-88,
  title = {{A CAD-based robot vision system}},
  author = {E. Gmur and H. Bunke},
  booktitle = {Proc. IASTED Int Symp. Applied Informatics (AI '88)},
  publisher = {ACTA Press},
  pages = {49--52},
  year = {1988},
  abstract = {A system for the recognition of 3-D solid objects from single
    gray level images is described. The object models are based on CAD-models
    which are generated using a commercial CAD-system. Vertices and edges
    are extracted from the gray level image by edge finding, curve segmentation
    and junction labeling. Object recognition is achieved by a two stage
    procedure. First, hypotheses are generated using a subgraph isomorphism
    procedure. Next, hypothesis verification through geometric projection
    is carried out. The system has been completely implemented in Pascal
    on a PRIME-750 and tested with a variety of object models and images.}}

@article{GraHar-CMA-88,
  title = {{Covering and packing in graphs V: Mispacking subcubes in hypercubes}},
  author = {N. Graham and Frank Harary},
  journal = {Computers and Mathematics with Applications},
  volume = {15},
  pages = {267--270},
  year = {1988},
  abstract = {For pt.IV see Networks, vol.11, p.69-72 (1981). A node-disjoint
    packing of a graph $G$ with a subgraph $H$ is a largest collection of
    disjoint copies of a smaller graph $H$ contained in $G$; an edge disjoint
    packing is defined similarly, but no two copies of $H$ have a common
    edge. Two packing numbers of $G$ with $H$ are defined accordingly. It
    is easy to determine both of these numbers when $H$ is a subcube of a
    hypercube $G$. A mispacking of $G$ with subgraphs $H$ is a minimum maximal
    collection of disjoint copies of $H$ whose removal from $G$ leaves no
    subgraph $H$. Two mispacking numbers of $G$ and $H$ are defined analogously
    to the packing numbers. Their exact determination is quite difficult
    but upper bounds are obtained. The covering number of $G$ by a subgraph
    $H$ is the smallest number of copies of $H$ whose union is all of $G$.
    This number is determined for $G=Q_n$, $H=Q_m$.}}

@article{GraSpe-CMB-71,
  title = {{A constructive solution to a tournament problem}},
  author = {Ronald L. Graham and Joel H. Spencer},
  journal = {Canad. Math. Bull.},
  volume = {14},
  pages = {45--48},
  year = {1971}}

@article{Gro-AC-92,
  title = {{On the randomized complexity of monotone graph properties}},
  author = {Hans Dietmar Gr{\"o}ger},
  journal = {Acta Cybernetica},
  volume = {10},
  pages = {119--127},
  year = {1992},
  review = {MR-94a:05191}}

@article{MR-94a:05191,
  reviews = {Gro-AC-92},
  journal = {Mathematical Reviews},
  publisher = {Amer. Math. Soc.},
  title = {{On the randomized complexity of monotone graph properties}},
  author = {Xue Liang Li},
  number = {94a:05191},
  year = {1994},
  text = {By refining A. C.-C. Yao's idea [in Proceedings of the 28th Annual
    Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (Los Angeles, CA, 1987),
    393--400, IEEE Comput. Soc. Press, Washington, DC, 1987; CCA 1988:12283],
    the author obtains a further improvement in the reductions of arbitrary
    graph properties to bipartite graph properties [see P. Hajnal, Combinatorica
    11 (1991), no. 2, 131--143; MR 93a:05118]. This yields a better uniform
    lower bound $\Omega(n\sp {3/2})$ for the randomized complexity of the
    subgraph isomorphism properties. Furthermore, the author shows that for
    a large variety of subgraph isomorphism properties as well as $k$-colourability,
    the randomized complexity is bounded below by $\Omega(n\sp 2)$.}}

@article{Gro-IPL-91,
  title = {{Further comments on the subtree isomorphism for ordered trees}},
  author = {R. Grossi},
  journal = {Information Processing Letters},
  volume = {40},
  pages = {255--256},
  year = {1991},
  abstract = {Makinen \cite{Mak-IPL-89} solved the following subtree isomorphism
    problem in linear time, by means of string matching: given two ordered
    trees $P$ and $T$, $|P|\le|T|$, decide whether $P$ is isomorphic to any
    subtree of $T$. A subtree of a tree $T$ is intended there, as a node
    of $T$ and all its descendants. Dublish \cite{Dub-IPL-90} published some
    comments on Makinen's solution for the problem. He showed a counterexample
    to the algorithm presented by Makinen, providing a much simpler method
    for solving the same problem without using the reduction to the (harder)
    string matching problem. The present paper clarifies that Makinen's algorithm
    can work correctly by adding a further step to the original (incomplete)
    coding phase. It notes that the more general problem of tree isomorphism
    for unordered rooted trees of size $n$, has been solved in $O(n)$ time:
    hence the ordered subtree isomorphism can be obtained as a special case
    of the latter problem.}}

@book{GST-91,
  title = {{Graph Structure Theory: Proc. Joint Summer Res. Conf. Graph Minors}},
  author = {Neil Robertson and Paul D. Seymour},
  series = {Contemporary Mathematics},
  publisher = {Amer. Math. Soc.},
  number = {147},
  year = {1991}}

@inproceedings{Guh-ICCD-87,
  title = {{Optimizing codes for concurrent fault detection in microprogrammed
    controllers}},
  author = {A. Guha},
  booktitle = {Proc. Int. Conf. Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
    (ICCD '87)},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  pages = {486--489},
  year = {1987},
  abstract = {A method is presented for optimizing the checking codes that
    are used for concurrent fault detection in microprogrammed controllers
    (MCs). The term optimization refers to minimizing code redundancy or
    size while maximizing fault coverage. It is shown how a tailored monitor
    circuit, designed to detect all prespecified faults that can occur in
    the MC, can be used to optimize the fault-detecting MC design. The monitor
    checks the control flow of the MC by generating codes, or keys, associated
    with each microinstruction. The redundancy of this fault-detecting MC
    design can be minimized using a technique dubbed subgraph isomorphism
    (SGI). SGI can be applied to the control flow graph in the microprogram
    to reduce the number of monitor states and the size of the error-detecting
    code while minimally degrading the fault coverage. Examples studied show
    that there may be significant scope for optimizing the MC.}}

@inproceedings{GupKalMah-SWAT-96,
  title = {{Vertex partitioning problems on partial $k$-trees}},
  author = {Arvind Gupta and Damon Kaller and Sanjeev Mahajan and Tom Shermer},
  booktitle = {Proc. 5th Scandinavian Worksh. Algorithm Theory},
  number = {1097},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {161--172},
  month = {July},
  year = {1996},
  abstract = {We describe a general approach to obtain polynomial-time algorithms
    over partial $k$-trees for graph problems in which the vertex set is
    to be partitioned in some way. We encode these problems with formulae
    of the {\em Extended Mondaic Second-order} (or EMS) logic. Such a formula
    can be translated into a polynomial-time algorithm automatically. We
    focus on the problem of partitioning a partial $k$-tree into induced
    subgraphs isomorphic to a fixed {\em pattern} graph; a distinct algorithm
    is derived for each pattern graph and each value of $k$. We use a ``pumping
    lemma'' to show that (for some pattern graphs) this problem cannot be
    encoded in the ``ordinary'' Monadic Second-order logic---from which a linear-time
    algorithm over partial $k$-trees would be obtained. Hence, an EMS formula
    is in some sense the strongest possible. As a further application of
    our general approach, we derive a polynomial-time algorithm to determine
    the maximum number of {\em co-dominating sets} into which the vertices
    of a partial $k$-tree can be partitioned. (A co-dominating set of a graph
    is a dominating set of its complement graph.)}}

@inproceedings{GupNis-STACS-96,
  title = {{Characterizing the complexity of subgraph isomorphism for graphs
    of bounded path-width}},
  author = {A. Gupta and N. Nishimura},
  booktitle = {Proc. 13th Symp. Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science},
  year = {1996}}

@inproceedings{GupNis-SWAT-94,
  title = {{Sequential and parallel algorithms for embedding problems on
    classes of partial $k$-trees}},
  author = {A. Gupta and N. Nishimura},
  booktitle = {Proc. 4th Scand. Worksh. Algorithm Theory},
  number = {824},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {172--182},
  year = {1994},
  abstract = {We present sequential and parallel algorithms for various embedding
    problems on bounded degree partial k-trees and k-connected partial k-trees;
    these include subgraph isomorphism and topological embedding, known to
    be NP-complete for general partial k-trees. As well as contributing to
    our understanding of the types of graphs for which these problems are
    tractable, the paper introduces methods for solving problems on graphs.
    In particular, we make use of the tree decomposition of the graph to
    apply techniques used to solve problems on trees to solve problems on
    partial k-trees.}}

@article{GupNis-TCS-96,
  title = {{The complexity of subgraph isomorphism for classes of partial
    $k$-trees}},
  author = {A. Gupta and N. Nishimura},
  journal = {Theoretical Computer Science},
  volume = {164},
  pages = {287--298},
  year = {1996},
  abstract = {We present a clear demarcation between classes of bounded tree-width
    graphs for which the subgraph isomorphism problem is NP-complete and
    those for which it can be solved in polynomial time. In previous work,
    it has been shown that this problem is solvable in polynomial time if
    the source graph either has bounded degree or is k-connected, for k the
    tree-width of the two graphs. As well, it has also been shown that for
    certain specific connectivity or degree conditions, the problem becomes
    NP-complete. Here we give a complete characterization of the complexity
    of this problem on bounded tree-width graphs for all possible connectivity
    conditions of the two input graphs. Specifically, we show that when the
    source graph is not k-connected or has more than k vertices of unbounded
    degree the problem is NP-complete; this answers an open question of Matou\v{s}ek
    and Thomas.
    
    Many of our reductions are restricted to using a subset of graphs of
    bounded tree-width, namely graphs of bounded path-width. As a direct
    result of our constructions, we also show that when the source and target
    graphs have connectivity less than k or at least one has k vertices of
    unbounded degree, the subgraph isomorphism problem for bounded path-width
    graphs is NP-complete.}}

@article{GusNouHou-CICS-91,
  title = {{The Substance Module: the representation, storage, and searching
    of complex structures}},
  author = {A. J. Gushurst and J. G. Nourse and W. D. Hounshell and B. A.
    Leland and D. G. Raich},
  journal = {J. Chemical Information and Computer Sciences},
  volume = {31},
  pages = {447--454},
  year = {1991},
  abstract = {Chemical structures are typically represented in computer programs
    as simple graphs, where atoms are represented by a list of nodes and
    the bonds by a list of nondirectional edges. While this convention allows
    for the representation of a large variety of chemical structures, it
    does not lend itself toward the representation of many common substances
    such as polymers, nonstoichiometric mixtures, and formulations. An extension
    to this convention has been developed which allows properties to be identified
    with a defined subgraph in a structure, an Sgroup. This extension has
    been implemented in the Substance Module, a new MACCS-II module, and
    is used to represent and search a much broader class of chemical substances.
    A description of the new representation and searching capabilities is
    given as well as examples of its use.}}

@article{Hag-CICS-92,
  title = {{Molecular substructure similarity searching: efficient retrieval
    in two-dimensional structure databases}},
  author = {T. R. Hagadone},
  journal = {J. Chemical Information and Computer Sciences},
  volume = {32},
  pages = {515--521},
  year = {1992},
  abstract = {Molecular substructure searching and full-structure similarity
    searching have become standard structure retrieval techniques in chemical
    database systems. While these search methods often provide useful results,
    they do not always meet the needs of the chemical database searcher.
    This paper describes the development of a substructure similarity (subsimilarity)
    search system that finds molecules containing a substructure that is
    similar to a query structure. It is argued that subsimilarity searching
    fulfils a retrieval need not met by existing search techniques. A major
    goal in the design of the system, the ability to execute a majority of
    subsimilarity searches interactively, was realized through a two-step
    search method that employs a unique subsimilarity screening step followed
    by an approximate maximal common subgraph matching step. User acceptance
    of subsimilarity searching and its application in the research environment
    are discussed within the context of Upjohn's Cousin chemical database
    system.}}

@article{Han-JKISS-94,
  title = {{Three types of reconfigurations in large scale cellular array
    processors: their mathematical characterization and computational complexity}},
  author = {J.-I. Han},
  journal = {J. Korea Information Science Society},
  volume = {21},
  pages = {383--392},
  year = {1994},
  abstract = {One important class of highly parallel computers includes the
    large scale cellular array processors that are built with VLSI (Very
    Large Scale Integration) or WSI (Wafer Scale Integration) technologies.
    Those cellular array processors consist of a large number of simple processing
    cells, all on a single chip or wafer, each interconnected only to its
    neighbors. The fundamental issues in those cellular array processors
    are fault-tolerant reconfiguration, functional reconfiguration, and their
    integration. Although configuration is an essential task in the reconfiguration
    process, no one has given its precise and formal definition properly.
    The issue of integrating fault-tolerant reconfiguration and functional
    reconfiguration has been addressed only recently, and to the best of
    the author's knowledge, no significant study has been done on that problem.
    This paper characterizes the configuration tasks in terms of subgraph
    homeomorphism, identifies the relation between them, and shows that any
    difference between them is only conceptual in integrated reconfiguration.
    Then, the paper discusses the computational complexity of each reconfiguration
    process, and shows two mappings that play a key role in the integrated
    reconfiguration process.}}

@article{Har-Algs-93,
  title = {{Minimum path bases}},
  author = {D. Hartvigsen},
  journal = {J. Algorithms},
  volume = {15},
  pages = {125--142},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {The author introduces a vector space associated with the paths
    and cycles in a graph (this space properly includes the well-known cycle
    space). He presents a polynomial algorithm for finding a minimum weight
    basis for this space; he then presents an application of this algorithm.
    The application is an algorithm that finds in a graph a minimum weight
    subgraph whose cycle space has specified dimension $k$ (when $k=1$, this
    is the problem of finding a minimum weight cycle in a graph). He then
    shows how this algorithm easily provides a new algorithm for the planar
    $k$-split problem; for a planar graph, this is the problem of finding
    a minimum weight set of edges whose deletion results in a graph with
    $k$ components (when $k$=2, this is the problem of finding a minimum
    cut in a planar graph). The algorithm for the application is polynomial
    for fixed $k$. In particular, for the planar three-split problem, the
    algorithm can be implemented with worst case time complexity $O(|V|^3)$,
    whereas the best previous algorithm has complexity $O(|V|^6\log|V|)$.}}

@article{HasHatSat-TIPSJ-93,
  title = {{Active viewpoint selection algorithm for polyhedral object recognition}},
  author = {R. Hashimoto and K. Hattori and Y. Sato},
  journal = {Trans. Information Processing Soc. of Japan},
  volume = {34},
  pages = {2193--2201},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {A method for polyhedral object recognition with an active vision
    system is described. The vision system equips a rangefinder and takes
    range maps for 3D objects from actively selected viewpoints. The models
    are described by 3D attributed graphs. Since a range map represents absolute
    location and size of an object surface, the subgraph matching is effectively
    applied between an object graph of model and a scene graph obtained from
    the range map. If one of the models was not uniquely assigned, the major
    feature differences among models are searched and the expected viewpoint
    is calculated to retry the recognition. Methods are presented for model
    description, graph matching, pose estimation, and viewpoint selection.
    Some computer simulated experimental results are indicated and discussed.}}

@article{Hay-IC-77,
  title = {{Uniform representations of structured patterns and an algorithm
    for the induction of contingency-response rules}},
  author = {F. Hayes-Roth},
  journal = {Information and Control},
  volume = {33},
  pages = {87--116},
  year = {1977},
  abstract = {Many events (patterns) may be described by structural (conjunctive
    relational) representations, and general computational behaviour may
    be represented in terms of a set of grammatical rules (productions, transformations)
    relating two such event representations as contingency and response components.
    Uniform representations and graphs of structural descriptions and rules
    are introduced. An abstraction of a set of uniform representations corresponds
    to a common subgraph of the corresponding uniform graphs. Every rule
    F=((for all $x_1,\ldots,x_n$)$C(x_1,\ldots,x_n)$ to $R(x_1,\ldots,x_n)$)
    which can be induced from a training set $I=((C_i,R_i): i=1,\ldots,N)$
    of contingency-response (input-output) pairs is identified with a common
    subgraph of the uniform graphs of the causal inferences $C_i$ to $R_i$.
    A general learning problem is formulated for which three cases are distinguishable
    on the basis of if and how substitutions from input to output patterns
    are to be made. Category (unary) and $n$-ary predicate learning in this
    framework are discussed. Examples of rule learning applications are drawn
    from the domains of transformational grammar. The properties (both desirable
    and undesirable) of the proposed approach and the differences between
    it and previous approaches are also considered.}}

@inproceedings{HerHorVei-BMVC-90,
  title = {{Symbolic image matching by simulated annealing}},
  author = {L. Herault and R. Horaud and F. Veillon and J. J. Niez},
  booktitle = {Proc. British Machine Vision Conference (BMVC90)},
  pages = {319--324},
  year = {1990},
  abstract = {The authors suggest an optimization approach to visual matching.
    They assume that the information available in an image may be conveniently
    represented symbolically in a relational graph. They concentrate on the
    problem of matching two such graphs. First they derive a cost function
    associated with graph matching and more precisely associated with relational
    subgraph isomorphism and with maximum relational subgraph matching. This
    cost function is well suited for optimization methods such as simulated
    annealing. They show how the graph matching problem is easily cast into
    a simulated annealing algorithm. Finally they show some preliminary experimental
    results and discuss the utility of this graph matching method in computer
    vision in general.}}

@inproceedings{HuaOve-ISCS-95,
  title = {{A novel graph algorithm for circuit recognition}},
  author = {K.-T. Huang and D. Overhauser},
  booktitle = {Proc. Int. Symp. Circuits and Systems},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  volume = {3},
  pages = {1695--1698},
  year = {1995},
  abstract = {This paper presents novel subcircuit recognition and verification
    algorithms based on a new technique for circuit graph coding. This coding
    uniquely identifies each subcircuit and is ideal for applications requiring
    circuit graph isomorphism in the presence of parasitics. These algorithms
    use a new circuit graph and graph isomorphism techniques to generate
    a unique code for each subcircuit, which has led to an improved circuit
    recognition algorithm.}}

@inproceedings{HunMarRad-ESA-94,
  title = {{A unified approach to approximation schemes for NP- and PSPACE-hard
    problems for geometric graphs}},
  author = {Hunt, III, H. B. and M. V. Marathe and V. Radhakrishnan and S.
    S. Ravi and D. J. Rosenkrantz and R. E. Stearns},
  booktitle = {Proc. 2nd Eur. Symp. Algorithms},
  number = {855},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {424--435},
  month = {September},
  year = {1994}}

@article{ItaRod-SJC-78,
  title = {{Finding a minimum circuit in a graph}},
  author = {A. Itai and M. Rodeh},
  journal = {SIAM J. Computing},
  publisher = {Soc. Industrial {\&} Applied Math.},
  volume = {7},
  pages = {413--423},
  year = {1978},
  abstract = {Finding minimum circuits in graphs and digraphs is discussed.
    An almost minimum circuit is a circuit which may have only one edge more
    than the minimum. To find an almost minimum circuit an $O(n^2)$ algorithm
    is presented. A direct algorithm for finding a minimum circuit has an
    $O(ne)$ behavior. It is refined to yield an $O(n^2)$ average time algorithm.
    An alternative method is to reduce the problem of finding a minimum circuit
    to that of finding a triangle in an auxiliary graph. Three methods for
    finding a triangle in a graph are given. The first has an $O(e^{3/2})$
    worst case bound ($O(n)$ for planar graphs); the second takes $O(n^{5/3})$
    time on the average; the third has an $O(n^{\log 7})$ worst case behavior.
    For digraphs, results of Bloniarz, Fisher and Meyer are used to obtain
    an algorithm with $O(n^2\log{n})$ average behavior.}}

@inproceedings{ItoNik-EMTS-91,
  title = {{Recognition of pattern defects of printed circuit board using
    topological information}},
  author = {M. Ito and Y. Nikaido},
  booktitle = {Proc. 11th Int. Electronics Manufacturing Technology Symp.},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers and CHMT},
  pages = {202--206},
  year = {1991},
  abstract = {The authors discuss an optical inspection system in which topological
    information on conductors and insulators of PCBs (printed circuit boards)
    is used for the detection of defects. The conventional image comparison
    methods, such as direct comparison of two images and image expansion-contraction
    for a design-rule inspection, have some difficulties in finding large
    defects, missing patterns, and a short. To cope with these problems,
    topological information on PCBs is introduced in this proposed method.
    This will also make it easy to access computer-aided design data for
    the inspection process. The principle of the system is mainly based on
    the topological comparison method which compares the inspection graph
    obtained from the skeletons of the conductor and insulator images of
    an inspection PCB with those of the standard or reference board. Topological
    information incorporates weighted graphs composed of several types of
    nodes and edges, connections, and their locations. Both conductor and
    insulator graphs have such information.}}

@article{JagStoTho-Comb-96,
  title = {{Multiplicities of subgraphs}},
  author = {Chris Jagger and Pavel {\v{S}}{\v{t}}ov{\'\i}{\v{c}}ek and Andrew
    Thomason},
  journal = {Combinatorica},
  volume = {16},
  number = {1},
  pages = {123--141},
  year = {1996}}

@inproceedings{JamOla-FSTTCS-89,
  title = {{A linear-time recognition algorithm for $P_4$-reducible graphs}},
  author = {B. Jamison and S. Olariu},
  booktitle = {Proc. 9th Conf. Foundations of Software Technology and Theoretical
    Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {1--19},
  year = {1989},
  abstract = {$P_4$-reducible graphs are precisely those graphs none of whose
    vertices belong to more than one chordless path with three edges. As
    it turns out, the class of $P_4$-reducible graphs strictly contains the
    well-known class of cographs. A remarkable property of $P_4$-reducible
    graphs is their unique tree representation up to isomorphism. The paper
    presents a linear-time algorithm to recognize $P_4$-reducible graphs
    and to construct their corresponding tree representation.}}

@article{JanLucRuc-RG-87,
  title = {{An exponential bound for the probability of nonexistence of specified
    subgraphs of a random graph}},
  author = {S. Janson and T. {\L}uczak and A. Rucinski},
  booktitle = {Proc. Random Graphs '87},
  publisher = {J. Wiley},
  pages = {73--87},
  year = {1987}}

@article{Kan-IPL-94,
  title = {{Maximum bounded $H$-matching is MAX SNP-complete}},
  author = {V. Kann},
  journal = {Information Processing Letters},
  volume = {49},
  pages = {309--318},
  year = {1994},
  abstract = {Proves that maximum H-matching (the problem of determining
    the maximum number of node-disjoint copies of the fixed graph H contained
    in a variable graph) is a MAX SNP-hard problem for any graph H that has
    three or more nodes in some connected component. If H is connected and
    the degrees of the nodes in H are bounded by a constant the problem is
    MAX SNP-complete.}}

@inproceedings{Kan-STACS-92,
  title = {{On the approximability of the maximum common subgraph problem}},
  author = {V. Kann},
  booktitle = {Proc. 9th Symp. Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science},
  number = {577},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {377--388},
  year = {1992},
  abstract = {Some versions of the maximum common subgraph problem are studied
    and approximation algorithms are given. The maximum bounded common induced
    subgraph problem is shown to be MAX SNP-hard and the maximum unbounded
    common induced subgraph problem is shown to be as hard to approximate
    as the maximum independent set problem. The maximum common induced connected
    subgraph problem is still harder to approximate and is shown to be NPO
    PB-complete, i.e. complete in the class of optimization problems with
    optimal value bounded by a polynomial.}}

@inproceedings{KanTamDiB-FOCS-91,
  title = {{On-line maintenance of the four-connected components of a graph}},
  author = {A. Kanevsky and R. Tamassia and Di Battista, G. and J. Chen},
  booktitle = {Proc. 32nd IEEE Symp. Foundations of Computer Science},
  pages = {793--801},
  year = {1991}}

@article{KasKitRos-PRL-83,
  title = {{A Hough transform technique for subgraph isomorphism}},
  author = {S. Kasif and L. Kitchen and A. Rosenfeld},
  journal = {Pattern Recognition Letters},
  volume = {2},
  pages = {83--88},
  year = {1983},
  abstract = {The generalized Hough transform is an established technique
    for geometric shape matching. An analogous technique is presented here
    for approximate solution of subgraph isomorphism problems. Its chief
    advantages are that it can also be used to find partial isomorphisms
    and that it can be readily implemented in parallel on a network of simple
    processors.}}

@article{KehMoh-CVGIP-89,
  title = {{A framework for estimation of motion parameters from range images}},
  author = {N. Kehtarnavaz and S. Mohan},
  journal = {Computer Vision, Graphics, and Image Processing},
  volume = {45},
  pages = {88--105},
  year = {1989},
  abstract = {A framework for inferring motion parameters of a moving object
    from its range image frames is presented. This framework is based on
    a correspondence approach where correspondences of view-invariant patches
    on the object surface are sought. From each range image, a relational
    graph is set up such that a node represents a view-invariant patch and
    an edge the adjacency of two such patches. Then, the largest subgraph
    common to two relational graphs is detected. This subgraph represents
    the same region visible in the corresponding range images. Finally, the
    motion parameters are estimated by minimizing the sum of squares error
    between the centers of mass of the common nodes in the largest matched
    subgraph. Examples of real range images show the merit of this framework.}}

@article{KeiBre-CMCC-91,
  title = {{The complexity of clustering in planar graphs}},
  author = {J. M. Keil and T. B. Brecht},
  journal = {J. Combinatorial Mathematics and Combinatorial Computing},
  volume = {9},
  pages = {155--159},
  year = {1991},
  abstract = {An h-cluster in a graph is a set of h vertices which maximizes
    the number of edges in the graph induced by these vertices. The authors
    show that the connected h-cluster problem is NP-complete on planar graphs.}}

@inproceedings{KhaMot-STOC-96,
  title = {{Towards a syntactic characterization of PTAS}},
  author = {Sanjeev Khanna and Rajeev Motwani},
  booktitle = {Proc. 28th ACM Symp. Theory of Computing},
  pages = {329--337},
  month = {May},
  year = {1996}}

@inproceedings{Khu-WADS-89,
  title = {{Parallel algorithms for the subgraph homeomorphism problem}},
  author = {Samir Khuller},
  booktitle = {Proc. 1st Worksh. Algorithms and Data Structures},
  number = {382},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  year = {1989}}

@inproceedings{KhuMitVaz-FOCS-89,
  title = {{Processor efficient parallel algorithms for the two disjoint
    paths problem, and for finding a Kuratowski homeomorph}},
  author = {Samir Khuller and S. G. Mitchell and V. V. Vazirani},
  booktitle = {Proc. 30th Symp. Foundations of Computer Science},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  pages = {300--305},
  year = {1989},
  abstract = {Given a graph $G$ and two pairs of vertices $s_1$, $t_1$ and
    $s_2$, $t_2$, the two disjoint paths problem asks for vertex-disjoint
    paths connecting $s_i$ with $t_i$, $i=1,2$. A fast parallel (NC) algorithm
    is given for this problem, which has applications in certain routing
    situations. If $G$ is nonplanar, an algorithm that finds a Kuratowski
    homeomorph in $G$ (i.e. a subgraph homeomorphic to $K_{3,3}$ or $K_5$)
    is given. This complements the known NC planarity algorithms, which give
    a planar embedding in the positive case; the algorithm provides a certificate
    of nonplanarity in the negative case. Both algorithms are processor efficient;
    in each case, the processor-time product is within a polylogarithmic
    factor of the best known sequential algorithm.}}

@article{Kin-ASU-93,
  title = {{Simula, subgraphs and financial policy}},
  author = {E. Kindler},
  journal = {ASU Newsletter},
  volume = {21},
  pages = {29--30},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {One can effectively use simulation languages for making non-simulation
    programs. An algorithm for computing the shortest path has been adapted
    for an implementation in Simula. The essence of the algorithm lies in
    modelling objects behaving according to certain rules which are listed
    by the author. Computing the shortest path can be considered as a special
    case of looking for a certain subgraph of an evaluated oriented graph.
    The main principle of the mentioned algorithm - a quasi-parallel system
    of migrating objects - can he applied in other problems concerning subgraphs.
    The author met that possibility in constructing some decision support
    programs in financial policy.}}

@article{Kit-SMC-80,
  title = {{Relaxation Applied to Matching Quantitative Relational Structures}},
  author = {L. Kitchen},
  journal = {Trans. Systems, Man and Cybernetics},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  volume = {10},
  pages = {96--101},
  year = {1980},
  abstract = {A relaxation process is applied to the problem of matching
    relational structures involving numeric quantities. The method is empirically
    shown to be very sensitive to the exact form of the updating rule used.
    However, with the proper updating rule, the method works well and is
    remarkably tolerant of measurement errors.}}

@article{KleSub-Algo-98,
  title = {{Fully dynamic approximation schemes for shortest path problems
    in planar graphs}},
  author = {P. N. Klein and S. Sairam},
  journal = {Algorithmica},
  volume = {22},
  number = {3},
  pages = {235--249},
  month = {November},
  year = {1998}}

@article{KleZiv-MCM-93,
  title = {{Subgraph generating functions in chemistry---an example for perfect
    matchings on honeycomb fragments}},
  author = {D. J. Klein and T. P. Zivkovic},
  journal = {Mathematical and Computer Modelling},
  volume = {17},
  pages = {113--123},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {The analogous role of subgraph generating functions in statistical
    mechanics and in quantum-chemical theory is noted. To illustrate the
    analogy, the example of perfect matchings on hexagonal animals is considered.
    Isomorphisms to two types of multiple-walk problems are noted to reveal
    a 'hidden order', with physical relevance. This is further used to accomplish
    enumeration of the perfect matchings on a class of hexagonal-animal strips
    of arbitrary width and length.}}

@inproceedings{KolVar-PODS-90,
  title = {{On the expressive power of Datalog: tools and a case study}},
  author = {P. G. Kolaitis and Moshe Y. Vardi},
  booktitle = {Proc. 9th Symp. Principles of Database Systems},
  publisher = {Assoc. Comput. Mach.},
  pages = {61--71},
  year = {1990},
  abstract = {The authors study the language Datalog(not=), which is the
    query language obtained from Datalog by allowing equalities and inequalities
    in the bodies of the rules. They view Datalog( not=) as a fragment of
    an infinitary logic L/sup omega / and show that L/sup omega / can be
    characterized in terms of certain two-person pebble games. This characterization
    provides tools for investigating the expressive power of Datalog( not=).
    As a case study, they classify the expressibility of fixed subgraph homeomorphism
    queries on directed graphs. The computational complexity of these queries
    has been classified by establishing two dichotomies, which are proper
    only if P not=NP. Without using any complexity-theoretic assumptions,
    the authors show that the two dichotomies are indeed proper in terms
    of expressibility in Datalog( not=).}}

@inproceedings{KorPel-FOCS-93,
  title = {{On choosing a dense subgraph}},
  author = {G. Kortsarz and D. Peleg},
  booktitle = {Proc. 34th Symp. Foundations of Computer Science},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  pages = {692--703},
  year = {1993},
  abstract = {This paper concerns the problem of computing the densest $k$-vertex
    subgraph of a given graph, namely, the subgraph with the most edges,
    or with the highest edges-to-vertices ratio. A sequence of approximation
    algorithms is developed for the problem, with each step yielding a better
    ratio at the cost of a more complicated solution. The approximation ratio
    of our final algorithm is $O(n^{0.3885})$. We also present a method for
    converting an approximation algorithm for an unweighted graph problem
    (from a specific class of maximization problems) into one for the corresponding
    weighted problem, and apply it to the densest subgraph problem.}}

@inproceedings{Kov-ICPR-86,
  title = {{Structural image analysis}},
  author = {V. Kovalevsky},
  booktitle = {Proc. 8th Int. Conf. Pattern Recognition},
  publisher = {Inst. Electrical {\&} Electronics Engineers},
  pages = {358--368},
  year = {1986},
  abstract = {A methodological justification of the hierarchical approach
    to structural analysis and of its relation to digital topology and image
    segmentation is presented. A consistent conception of digital spaces
    based on the classical notion of a complex is given, and its advantages
    are demonstrated. Achievements in image segmentation are analyzed and
    compared. The techniques of subgraph isomorphism, consistent labeling,
    graph grammars, and relational matching as applied to image analysis
    are surveyed and their possibilities are discussed. An original method
    of hierarchical relational matching is described and an example of its
    application to recognizing hand-printed characters.}}

@inproceedings{KozBenSti-EGP-99,
  title = {{Genetic programming as a Darwinian invention machine}},
  author = {John R. Koza and Bennett, III, Forrest H. and Oscar Stiffelman},
  booktitle = {Proc. 2nd Worksh. Genetic Programming (EuroGP '99)},
  number = {1598},
  editor = {Riccardo Poli and Peter Nordin and William B. Langdon and Terence
    C. Fogarty},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  year = {1999},
  url = {http://www.genetic-programming.com/EUROGP99.ps},
  abstract = {Genetic programming is known to be capable of creating designs
    that satisfy prespecified high-level design requirements for analog electrical
    circuits and other complex structures. However, in the real world, it
    is often important that a design satisfy various non-technical requirements.
    One such requirement is that a design not possess the key characteristics
    of any previously known design. This paper shows that genetic programming
    can be used to generate novel solutions to a design problem so that genetic
    programming may be potentially used as an invention machine. This paper
    turns the clock back to the period just before the time (1917) when George
    Campbell of American Telephone and Telegraph invented and patented the
    design for an electrical circuit that is now known as the ladder filter.
    Genetic programming is used to reinvent the Campbell filter. The paper
    then turns the clock back to the period just before the time (1928) when
    Wilhelm Cauer invented and patented the elliptic filter. Genetic programming
    is then used to reinvent a technically equivalent filter that avoids
    the key characteristics of then-preexisting Campbell filter. Genetic
    programming can be used as an invention machine by employing a two-part
    fitness measure that incorporates both the degree to which an individual
    in the population satisfies the given technical requirements and the
    degree to which the individual does not possess the key characteristics
    of preexisting technology.},
  comment = {Uses subgraph isomorphism techniques to measure the similarity
    between electronic circuits in the genetic algorithms's population and
    some known circuit whose features are to be avoided for patent infringement
    reasons. From section 4.5: "The factor of the fitness measure pertaining
    to similarity to the to-be-avoided ladder filter is measured in terms
    of the largest number of nodes and edges (circuit components) of a subgraph
    of the given circuit that is isomorphic to a subgraph of a template."}}

@inproceedings{KraProTel-WG-94,
  title = {{Complexity of graph covering problems}},
  author = {Jan Kratochv{\'\i}l and A. Proskurowski and J. A. Telle},
  booktitle = {Proc. 20th Int. Worksh. Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer
    Science},
  number = {903},
  series = {Lecture Notes in Computer Science},
  publisher = {Springer-Verlag},
  pages = {93--105},
  year = {1994},
  abstract = {Given a fixed graph $H$, the $H$-cover problem asks whether
    an input graph $G$ allows a degree preserving mapping $f:V(G)\mapsto
    V(H)$ such that for every $v$ in $V(G)$, $f(N_G(v))=N_H(f(v))$. In this
    paper, we design efficient algorithms for certain graph covering problems
    according to two basic techniques. The first one is a reduction to the
    2-SAT problem. The second technique exploits necessary and sufficient
    conditions for the existence of regular factors in graphs. For other
